summaryOfNewsArticle: A new immigration policy introduced by the government on April 10, 2024, has sparked widespread concern among human rights organizations and international experts. The policy, which affects asylum seekers and refugees, is being criticized for potentially violating international human rights standards. On April 12, Human Rights Watch filed a formal complaint over the treatment of asylum seekers in detention centers, citing poor living conditions, lack of access to legal counsel, and psychological distress. The International Committee of the Red Cross has similarly expressed concern about the lack of medical care and legal representation for detainees. On April 14, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights announced that an independent review of the policy will be conducted to evaluate its compliance with international law. The key takeaway is that while the policy aims to strengthen national border control, its implementation may undermine fundamental human rights. International experts are urging the government to revise the policy to ensure it respects the rights of vulnerable populations, particularly asylum seekers and refugees. The period from April 5 to April 20, 2024, is considered critical for monitoring the policy's impact, with ongoing assessments by global organizations.
title: New Immigration Policy Sparks Human Rights Concerns
